q: What are common causes of smelly pee?
a: Common causes of smelly pee include certain types of food and drink, dehydration, certain medications, and vitamin B6 supplements. In some cases, it can be caused by a urinary tract infection or other underlying conditions such as type 2 diabetes or kidney stones.

q: How can I help my pee return to normal if it smells?
a: To help your pee return to normal, you can drink plenty of fluids, particularly water, to stay hydrated. Avoid consuming sugary fizzy drinks, coffee, or alcohol, and limit your intake of garlic or asparagus as they can contribute to strong-smelling pee. Additionally, avoid taking more than 10mg of vitamin B6 per day.

q: When should I see a doctor for smelly pee?
a: You should see a GP if you have smelly pee and experience symptoms such as sudden and frequent urination, pain or burning sensation when peeing, cloudy urine. If you have blood in your urine, lower tummy pain, pain in your back, fatigue, confusion, high or low temperature, seek urgent medical advice from NHS 111 or your GP.

q: What should I do if there's blood in my pee?
a: If you have smelly pee and notice blood in your urine, it is important to seek immediate medical attention. Ask for an urgent GP appointment or contact NHS 111 for assistance.

q: Can certain foods and drinks make my pee smell stronger?
a: Yes, certain types of food and drinks such as asparagus or coffee can make your pee smell stronger. These foods contain chemicals that can pass into your urine and contribute to the odor.

q: What are the symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: Common symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) include pain or a burning sensation when peeing, frequent urination, cloudy urine, and smelly pee. If you experience these symptoms, it is recommended to see a GP for further evaluation and treatment.

q: How much water should I drink to help keep my pee clear and mild-smelling?
a: It is recommended to drink plenty of fluids, particularly water, to keep your pee clear and mild-smelling. The exact amount of water you should drink may vary depending on factors such as your activity level and climate. In general, aim to drink enough water so that you pee regularly throughout the day and do not feel thirsty.

q: Are there any specific medications that can cause smelly pee?
a: Yes, some medications can contribute to smelly pee. If you are taking any medications and notice a change in the odor of your urine, it is advisable to consult with your healthcare provider for further guidance.

q: What are some other conditions that can cause smelly pee?
a: In addition to urinary tract infections, smelly pee can be caused by other conditions such as type 2 diabetes or kidney stones. If you suspect an underlying condition is causing the change in odor, it is best to consult with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and diagnosis.

q: What are the non-urgent symptoms that I should see a doctor for if I have smelly pee?
a: Non-urgent symptoms that you should see a doctor for if you have smelly pee include sudden and frequent urination, pain or a burning sensation when peeing, and cloudy urine. It is recommended to schedule an appointment with a GP for further assessment.

a: To help reduce the smell of your pee, you can drink plenty of fluids, especially water, stay hydrated, avoid sugary fizzy drinks, coffee, alcohol, garlic, and asparagus. Limit your intake of vitamin B6 to 10mg a day.

a: If you have smelly pee along with symptoms like blood in urine, lower tummy pain, back pain under the ribs, fatigue, confusion, high temperature, or feeling hot and shivery, it is recommended to seek urgent medical attention by calling NHS 111 or getting help online.

q: Does drinking more fluids help with smelly pee?
a: Yes, drinking plenty of fluids, particularly water, can help dilute the urine and reduce the concentration of strong-smelling substances, thereby improving the odor of pee.

a: Yes, certain foods and drinks like asparagus and coffee can contribute to stronger-smelling pee due to the presence of chemicals that can pass into the urine.

q: Is smelly pee ever caused by conditions like type 2 diabetes or kidney stones?
a: Yes, although less commonly, smelly pee can be caused by conditions like type 2 diabetes or kidney stones. If you suspect any underlying medical condition, it is advisable to seek medical evaluation.

q: What should I avoid if I have smelly pee?
a: If you have smelly pee, it is recommended to avoid consuming excessive amounts of sugary fizzy drinks, coffee, alcohol, garlic, or asparagus, as these can contribute to stronger-smelling urine.

q: Is it normal to have smelly pee occasionally?
a: Occasional mild changes in the odor of urine are usually normal and may be influenced by certain foods or medications. However, if the odor persists or is accompanied by other symptoms, it is advisable to consult a healthcare professional.
